Growl.name: Growl
description: Growl lowers the target's Attack by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Growl turns into Z-Growl and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Tackle.name: Tackle
description: Tackle is one of the most common and basic moves a Pokémon learns. It deals damage with no additional effects.
In Generations 1-4, Tackle has 35 base power.
In Generations 5-6, Tackle has 50 base power.
In Generations 1-4, Tackle has 95% accuracy.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Tackle turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.

Vine Whip.name: Vine Whip
description: Vine Whip deals damage with no additional effect.
In Generations 1-3, Vine Whip is categorized as Special.
In Generations 1-5, Vine Whip has 35 base power.
In Generations 1-3, Vine Whip has 10 PP.
In Generations 4-5, Vine Whip has 15 PP.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Vine Whip turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 100.

Growth.name: Growth
description: Growth raises the user's Attack and Special Attack by one stage each. During harsh sunlight it raises each stat by two stages.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
In Generations 1-5, Growth has 40 PP.

In Generations 1-4, Growth only increases Special Attack, and harsh sunlight does not affect it. In Generation 1 it increases the Special stat, which in those games encompasses Special Attack and Special Defense.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Growth turns into Z-Growth and raises Special Attack one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Leech Seed.name: Leech Seed
description: Leech Seed plants a seed on the target that drains 1⁄8 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn and restores it to the user, or any Pokémon that takes its place. It does not work on Grass-type Pokémon; it does technically work against Pokémon with the Magic Guard ability, but no HP will be sapped.

If the user is holding a Big Root, the move still saps the same amount of HP but recovers 30% more than normal. For example, if a Pokémon has 320 HP, Leech Seed would cause them to lose 40 HP each turn but the seeder would recover 52 HP.
If used on a Pokémon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained. The seeded Pokémon can clear Leech Seed by switching out or using Rapid Spin.

In Generation 1, Leech Seed saps 1⁄16 of the target's HP. If the target is also badly poisoned, the damage increases by 1⁄16 each turn, in the same way as bad poison (and in addition to poison damage).
In Generation 1 and Generation 2 only, Haze will also clear the effects of Leech Seed.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Leech Seed turns into Z-Leech Seed and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Razor Leaf.name: Razor Leaf
description: Razor Leaf deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄24).
In Generations 1-3, Razor Leaf is categorized as Special.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Razor Leaf turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 100.

Poison Powder.name: Poison Powder
description: Poison Powder causes the target to become poisoned. Poisoned Pokémon lose 1⁄8 of their maximum HP each turn.
Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
In Generations 1-5, this move's name is formatted as PoisonPowder.
When a Pokémon is holding Poisonium Z and uses its Z-Power, Poison Powder turns into Z-Poison Powder and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Sleep Powder.name: Sleep Powder
description: Sleep Powder puts the target to sleep, if it hits. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns.
Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Sleep Powder turns into Z-Sleep Powder and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Seed Bomb.name: Seed Bomb
description: Seed Bomb deals damage with no additional effect.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Seed Bomb turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 160.

Take Down.name: Take Down
description: Take Down deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄4 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 25 HP.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Take Down turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 175.

Sweet Scent.name: Sweet Scent
description: Sweet Scent lowers the target's Evasion by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Sweet Scent turns into Z-Sweet Scent and raises Accuracy one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

While standing in any area where a Pokémon could appear (e.g. tall grass, in a cave, surfing on water), Sweet Scent will make a wild Pokémon automatically appear. In Generation 6, Sweet Scent will often initiate a Horde Encounter with 5 wild Pokémon.
In Generations 4-5 and Pokémon X/Y, Sweet Scent can only be used when there is no weather condition (e.g. rain) present.

Synthesis.name: Synthesis
description: User recovers HP. Amount varies with the weather.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Synthesis turns into Z-Synthesis and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Worry Seed.name: Worry Seed
description: Worry Seed changes the target's ability to Insomnia, which prevents the Pokémon from falling asleep. If the move is used on a sleeping Pokémon, it will wake up on its next turn.
Worry Seed does not work on Pokémon with the ability Truant or Multitype.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Worry Seed turns into Z-Worry Seed and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Double-Edge.name: Double-Edge
description: Double-Edge deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄3 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 90 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 30 HP.
In Generation 1, Double-Edge has 100 base power.
In Generations 1-2, the recoil is 1⁄4 of the damage inflicted.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Double-Edge turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 190.

Solar Beam.name: Solar Beam
description: The user of Solar Beam will absorb light on the first turn. On the second turn, Solar Beam deals damage.
During intense sunlight or when holding a Power Herb, Solar Beam executes in one turn. During rain, hail or a sandstorm its power decreases by 50%.
In Pokémon Let's Go Pikachu & Let's Go Eevee, Solar Beam has 200 base power.
In Generations 1-5, this move's name is formatted as SolarBeam.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Solar Beam turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 190.

Amnesia.name: Amnesia
description: Amnesia raises the user's Special Defense by two stages.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Amnesia turns into Z-Amnesia and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Charm.name: Charm
description: Charm lowers the target's Attack by two stages.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generations 2-5, Charm is a Normal-type move.
When a Pokémon is holding Fairium Z and uses its Z-Power, Charm turns into Z-Charm and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Curse.name: Curse
description: Curse is a unique move that works differently for Ghost-type Pokémon than other Pokémon.

Ghost-type Pokémon use 50% of their maximum HP to place a curse on the target. The cursed Pokémon loses 25% of their maximum HP every turn. If the user has less than 50% HP remaining, they will faint but the curse still takes effect.

For all other Pokémon, Curse raises the user's Attack and Defense by one stage each and lowers Speed by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each, or lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generations 1-4, Curse is a ???-type move.

When a Pokémon is holding Ghostium Z and uses its Z-Power, Curse turns into Z-Curse and either fully restores the user's HP if it is Ghost type, or raises Attack one stage otherwise, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Grassy Terrain.name: Grassy Terrain
description: Grassy Terrain creates a low-lying grassy field lasting 5 turns, that restores the HP of grounded Pokémon each turn, by 1⁄16 of their maximum HP. The power of Grass type moves also increases by 50% while in effect, and the moves Earthquake, Magnitude, and Bulldoze halve in power.
Grounded Pokémon are simply those that are not raised. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary.
Grassy Terrain is a terrain condition and can coexist at the same time as weather conditions, but not other terrain conditions.
The move Nature Power turns into Energy Ball under Grassy Terrain.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Grassy Terrain turns into Z-Grassy Terrain and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Ingrain.name: Ingrain
description: The user of Ingrain plants it roots, which restores 1⁄16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn, but prevents switching out.
Only the moves Baton Pass, U Turn or Volt Switch will allow the user to switch out, with Baton Pass transferring the effects of Ingrain. Moves such as Roar used on this Pokémon will have no effect.
Ingrain cancels effects given to raised Pokémon such as immunity to Ground-type moves, Spikes and so on. See more in the glossary.
If the user is holding a Big Root, Ingrain restores 30% more HP each turn - approximately 1⁄12 of its maximum.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Ingrain turns into Z-Ingrain and raises Special Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Leaf Storm.name: Leaf Storm
description: Leaf Storm deals damage but lowers the user's Special Attack by two stages after attacking.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generations 4-5, Leaf Storm has 140 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Leaf Storm turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 195.

Magical Leaf.name: Magical Leaf
description: Magical Leaf deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Magical Leaf turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 120.

Nature Power.name: Nature Power
description: When Nature Power is used it turns into a different move depending on the current battle terrain, as listed below.

Although it's a Normal type move, the user only receives STAB if the move it turns into is their type. For example, Sawsbuck (Normal/Grass) would not obtain STAB if Nature Power turned into Hydro Pump, but Ludicolo would.
Note: the category shown is as it was in Generation 3.

In Generations 3-5, Nature Power is set to target the user, but attacks the Pokémon directly opposite it on the battlefield (or an adjacent foe in double/triple battles if there is no Pokémon opposite). Moves that target multiple Pokémon such as Rock Slide still hit those targets as normal.

When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Nature Power turns into Z-Nature Power and becomes the Z-Move for the move selected (for example Hydro Vortex when on water), in addition to its usual effect as above.

Petal Dance.name: Petal Dance
description: The user of Petal Dance attacks for 2-3 turns, during which it cannot switch out, and then becomes confused. Confused Pokémon have a 33% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 attacking turns (50% chance in Generations 1-6). The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack.
If Petal Dance is disrupted (e.g. if the move misses or the user cannot attack due to paralysis) then it will stop and not cause confusion.
Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
In Generations 1-3, Petal Dance has 70 base power.
In Generation 4, Petal Dance has 90 base power.
In Generations 1-4, Petal Dance has 20 PP.
In Generations 1-4, the sleep, freezing and flinching status conditions will pause but not disrupt Petal Dance.
In Generation 1, Petal Dance lasts for 3-4 turns.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Petal Dance turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 190.

Power Whip.name: Power Whip
description: Power Whip deals damage with no additional effect.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Power Whip turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 190.

Skull Bash.name: Skull Bash
description: The user of Skull Bash will tuck in its head on the first turn and raise its Defense by one stage. On the second turn, Skull Bash deals damage.
If the user is holding a Power Herb, Skull Bash executes in one turn.
In Generations 1-5, Skull Bash has 100 base power.
In Generations 1-5, Skull Bash has 15 PP.
In Generation 1, Skull Bash does not raise the user's Defense.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Skull Bash turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 195.

Sludge.name: Sludge
description: Sludge deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target.
Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
In Generations 1-3, Sludge is categorized as Physical.
When a Pokémon is holding Poisonium Z and uses its Z-Power, Sludge turns into Acid Downpour and has base power 120.

Toxic.name: Toxic
description: Toxic causes the target to be badly poisoned. Pokémon that are badly poisoned will lose an increasing amount of HP at the end of each turn.
The affected Pokémon will lose 1⁄16 of its maximum HP at the end of the first turn, which then increases by 1⁄16 each turn. In other words, they lose 1⁄16, 2⁄16, 3⁄16, 4⁄16 and so on.
Toxic doesn't affect Pokémon already carrying a major status ailment, Pokémon behind a Substitute nor Poison- or Steel-type Pokémon.
In Generations 1-4, Toxic has 85% accuracy.
In Generation 1, Toxic also increases the damage taken by Leech Seed.
When a Pokémon is holding Poisonium Z and uses its Z-Power, Toxic turns into Z-Toxic and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Grassy Glide.name: Grassy Glide
description: High priority during Grassy Terrain.

Bullet Seed.name: Bullet Seed
description: Bullet Seed hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown in the table, with the total power after each hit.
Each strike of Bullet Seed is treated like a separate attack:
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
The Skill Link ability will cause Bullet Seed to always hit the maximum number of times.
In Generation 3, Bullet Seed is categorized as Special.
In Generations 3-4, Bullet Seed has 10 base power.
In Generations 3-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint.
In Generation 3, Bullet Seed ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Bullet Seed turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 140.

Work Up.name: Work Up
description: Work Up raises the user's Attack and Special Attack by one stage each.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Work Up turns into Z-Work Up and raises Attack one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Sunny Day.name: Sunny Day
description: Sunny Day causes bright sunlight that lasts for 5 turns, and induces these additional effects:
The power of Fire-type moves increases by 50%.
The power of Water-type moves decreases by 50%.
The accuracy of Thunder and Hurricane lowers to 50%.
Solar Beam and Solar Blade do not require the charging turn and attack straight away.
From Generation 5 onward, Growth raises Attack and Special Attack two stages each.
The moves Synthesis, Morning Sun and Moonlight recover 2⁄3 of the user's max HP (instead of the usual 1⁄2 HP).
The move Weather Ball changes to Fire type and doubles in power.
Pokémon with the ability Chlorophyll double their speed.
Pokémon with the ability Dry Skin lose 1⁄8 of their max HP each turn.
Pokémon with the ability Leaf Guard cannot be afflicted by major status conditions.
The Special Attack of Pokémon with the ability Solar Power increases by 50%.
Cherrim changes into Sunshine Form and its ability Flower Gift increases Attack and Special Defense.
Castform changes to Sunny Form.
Pokémon cannot be frozen.
When a Pokémon is holding Firium Z and uses its Z-Power, Sunny Day turns into Z-Sunny Day and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Light Screen.name: Light Screen
description: Light Screen reduces damage from Special attacks by 50%, for 5 turns. Its effects apply to all Pokémon on the user's side of the field.
If the user is holding Light Clay when Light Screen is used, its effects last for 8 turns.
The move Brick Break, when used against an Pokémon under Light Screen's effect, will remove the screen before dealing damage. The ability Infiltrator bypasses the effects of Light Screen.
Light Screen is the Special counterpart to Reflect.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Light Screen turns into Z-Light Screen and raises Special Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Protect.name: Protect
description: Protect prevents any attacks targeted at the user from striking, for the duration of the turn. It has priority +4 so will activate before most other moves. The move functions identically to Detect.
The accuracy of Protect decreases by 1⁄3 each time it is used consecutively after itself or Detect, Endure, Wide Guard, Quick Guard, Spiky Shield, King's Shield, or Baneful Bunker.
Damage-dealing Z-Moves bypass Protect but deal 1⁄4 of the damage.
In Generation 2, Protect has a priority of +2.
In Generations 3-4, Protect has a priority of +3.

In Generations 2-5, the accuracy of Protect decreases by 1⁄2 each time it is used consecutively after itself or any protecting move listed above. In Generation 4 only, it has a minimum accuracy of 1⁄8 (i.e. from the fourth consecutive use onwards).
In Diamond and Pearl only, Thunder during rain and Blizzard during hail have a 30% chance to bypass Protect.
In Generation 2, Protect will fail if the user is behind a Substitute.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Protect turns into Z-Protect and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Giga Drain.name: Giga Drain
description: Giga Drain deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained.

If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokémon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
In Generations 1-4, Giga Drain has 60 base power.
In Generations 1-3, Giga Drain has 5 PP.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Giga Drain turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 140.

Safeguard.name: Safeguard
description: The user's party is protected from status conditions.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Safeguard turns into Z-Safeguard and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Double Team.name: Double Team
description: Double Team raises the user's Evasiveness by one stage, thus making the user more difficult to hit.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Double Team turns into Z-Double Team and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Sludge Bomb.name: Sludge Bomb
description: Sludge Bomb deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target.
Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
In Generations 2-3, Sludge Bomb is categorized as Physical.
When a Pokémon is holding Poisonium Z and uses its Z-Power, Sludge Bomb turns into Acid Downpour and has base power 175.

Facade.name: Facade
description: Facade deals damage, and hits with double power (140) if the user is burned, poisoned or paralyzed.
In the case of a burn, the usual attack-halving still occurs so Facade hits with an effective power of 70.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Facade turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 140.

Rest.name: Rest
description: User sleeps for 2 turns, but user is fully healed.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Rest turns into Z-Rest and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Attract.name: Attract
description: Attract causes Pokémon of the opposite gender to become infatuated. Infatuated Pokémon have a 50% chance of being immobilized by love each turn and unable to attack.

Attract will fail on Pokémon of the same gender, genderless Pokémon and those with the ability Oblivious. Mew and Cryogonal can learn Attract via TM despite being genderless, however, the move will have no effect.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Attract turns into Z-Attract and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Energy Ball.name: Energy Ball
description: Energy Ball deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generations 4-5, Energy Ball has 80 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Energy Ball turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 175.

False Swipe.name: False Swipe
description: Always leaves opponent with at least 1 HP.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, False Swipe turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.

Endure.name: Endure
description: Endure allows the user to survive all attacks during the turn with at least 1 HP (even if it already has 1 HP remaining). It has priority +4 so will activate before most other moves.
The accuracy of Endure decreases by 1⁄3 each time it is used consecutively after itself or Protect, Detect, Wide Guard, Quick Guard, Spiky Shield, King's Shield, or Baneful Bunker.
In Generation 2, Endure has a priority of +2.
In Generations 3-4, Endure has a priority of +3.

In Generations 2-5, the accuracy of Endure decreases by 1⁄2 each time it is used consecutively after itself or any protecting move listed above. In Generation 4 only, it has a minimum accuracy of 1⁄8 (i.e. from the fourth consecutive use onwards).
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Endure turns into Z-Endure and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Flash.name: Flash
description: Flash lowers the target's Accuracy by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
In Generations 1-3, Flash has 70% accuracy.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Flash turns into Z-Flash and raises Evasiveness one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Flash lights up dark caves. In the original games dark caves made the screen almost completely black, whereas in later games you can always see a very short distance around you; Flash merely expands that circle. In the games it is an HM, it can only be used with the appropriate Gym Badge.

Swords Dance.name: Swords Dance
description: Swords Dance raises the user's Attack by two stages.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
In Generations 1-5, Swords Dance has 30 PP.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Swords Dance turns into Z-Swords Dance and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Sleep Talk.name: Sleep Talk
description: User performs one of its own moves while sleeping.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Sleep Talk turns into Z-Sleep Talk and raises critical-hit ratio one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Grass Knot.name: Grass Knot
description: Grass Knot inflicts greater damage on heavier opponents, as shown in the table.
For reference, the following Pokémon take 120 base damage from Grass Knot. From Generation 5 onwards, heavy Pokémon kick up dust as they land switching in.

When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Grass Knot turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 160.

Swagger.name: Swagger
description: Swagger confuses the target and raises its Attack by two stages.

If one of the two effects cannot be invoked (for example the target is already confused or its Attack is already raised to the maximum of +6 stages), Swagger still works and will invoke the other effect.

Confused Pokémon have a 33% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 attacking turns (50% chance in Generations 1-6). The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack.
In Generations 2-6, Swagger has 90% accuracy.
In Generation 2, if the target's Attack is already raised to the maximum +6 stages, Swagger will fail.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Swagger turns into Z-Swagger and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Substitute.name: Substitute
description: Uses HP to creates a decoy that takes hits.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Substitute turns into Z-Substitute and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Cut.name: Cut
description: Cut deals damage with no additional effect in battle.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Cut turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.
Cut is used to tear down small trees in your path. In Generations 1-6 it can only be used with the appropriate Gym Badge.
In Generations 1-3, Cut can also remove patches of grass. In Emerald, Pokémon with the Hyper Cutter ability remove a larger patch of grass.

Strength.name: Strength
description: Strength deals damage with no additional effect in battle.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Strength turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 160.
Strength is used to move large boulders in the field. Boulders can only be pushed, not pulled. It can only be used with the appropriate Gym Badge.
From Generation 5 onwards, boulders moved by Strength are often used to create shortcuts through caves and routes.

Rock Smash.name: Rock Smash
description: Rock Smash deals damage and has a 50% chance of lowering the target's Defense by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generations 1-3, Rock Smash has 20 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Fightinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Rock Smash turns into All-Out Pummeling and has base power 100.

Rock Smash breaks certain rocks that may be in your path. Smashing rocks may uncover wild Pokémon or items. Breakable rocks appear in Generations 2-4 and Generation 6. Only rocks in Johto/Hoenn reveal Pokémon/items when smashed.

Snore.name: Snore
description: Snore deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). However, it can only be used while the user is asleep (either from a move like Hypnosis or self-induced via Rest).
Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
In Generations 2-3, Snore is categorized as Physical.
In Generations 2-5, Snore has 40 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Snore turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.

Helping Hand.name: Helping Hand
description: In Double Battles, boosts the power of the partner's move.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Helping Hand turns into Z-Helping Hand and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Weather Ball.name: Weather Ball
description: The power and type of Weather Ball changes with the weather. With no weather condition it is Normal and has a base power of 50. If a weather condition is in effect, its power doubles to 100 and the move becomes a different type:
Bright sunlight: Fire type
Heavy rain: Water type
Sandstorm: Rock type
Hailstorm: Ice type

Beat Up.name: Beat Up
description: Beat Up deals damage from each Pokémon on your team that does not have a status ailment (nor is fainted). Each strike has a different base power, calculated as:

However, the actual attack is carried out by the original user of Beat Up, so it will always use that Pokémon's current attack stat to calculate damage. It will also receive any boosts from the originating user, such as STAB and any applicable items. However, any items held by the rest of the team do not affect the damage dealt.
Each strike of Beat Up is treated like a separate attack:
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.

Let's say we have the ultimate team of 1 Weavile and 5 Magikarp. One of the Magikarp is paralyzed, so only 4 can attack with Beat Up. Weavile's base Attack is 120, while Magikarp's is an incredible 10. Beat Up would attack 5 times, first with 17 base power (120 ÷ 10 + 5) and then 4 times with 6 base power (10 ÷ 10 + 5). The result would be as if Weavile had attacked with a Dark type move of 41 base power.
In a more realistic scenario, the average total base power for Beat Up is typically around 60-90.
In Generations 2-3, Beat Up is categorized as Special.
In Generations 2-4, Beat Up deals 10 base power typeless damage from each able Pokémon (using each Pokémon's Attack stat).
In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint.
In Generations 2-3, Beat Up ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
When a Pokémon is holding Darkinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Beat Up turns into Black Hole Eclipse and has base power 100.

description: Hits multiple opponents and lowers their attack. (100% chance)

Blaze Kick.name: Blaze Kick
description: Blaze Kick deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target. It also has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄24).

Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. Pokémon with the abilities Battle Armor or Shell Armor, or those under the effects of Lucky Chant, are protected against critical hits.
In Generation 3, Blaze Kick is categorized as Special.
When a Pokémon is holding Firium Z and uses its Z-Power, Blaze Kick turns into Inferno Overdrive and has base power 160.

Heat Crash.name: Heat Crash
description: Heat Crash inflicts more damage the heavier the user compared to the opponent. The table shows the different base powers for each ratio, where r = UserWeight ÷ TargetWeight
For example, if the user's weight is at least 4 times more than the target but less than 5 times, Heat Crash hits with 100 base power.
If the target has used Minimize, Heat Crash ignores accuracy and deals double damage.
In Generation 5, the Minimize effect did not occur.
When a Pokémon is holding Firium Z and uses its Z-Power, Heat Crash turns into Inferno Overdrive and has base power 160.

Hurricane.name: Hurricane
description: Hurricane deals damage and has a 30% chance of confusing the target.
Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
If used during rain, Hurricane ignores accuracy. Conversely, if used during intense sunlight, its accuracy drops to 50%. Hurricane can hit Pokémon in the invulnerable stage of Fly and Bounce.
In Generation 5, Hurricane has 120 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Hurricane turns into Supersonic Skystrike and has base power 185.

Tail Whip.name: Tail Whip
description: Tail Whip lowers the target's Defense by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Tail Whip turns into Z-Tail Whip and raises Attack one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Water Gun.name: Water Gun
description: Water Gun deals damage with no additional effect.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Water Gun turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 100.

Withdraw.name: Withdraw
description: Withdraw raises the user's Defense by one stage.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Withdraw turns into Z-Withdraw and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Rapid Spin.name: Rapid Spin
description: Rapid Spin deals damage, raises the user's Speed by one stage, and removes the effects of several trap moves and entry hazards. It fails if the move misses or the target is immune. The effects from the following moves are removed:
Bind
Clamp
Fire Spin
Infestation
Leech Seed
Magma Storm
Sand Tomb
Spikes
Stealth Rock
Sticky Web
Toxic Spikes
Whirlpool
Wrap
In Generations 2-7, Rapid Spin has 20 base power.
In Generations 2-7, Rapid Spin does not raise the user's Speed.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Rapid Spin turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.

Water Pulse.name: Water Pulse
description: Water Pulse deals damage and has a 20% chance of confusing the target.
Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Water Pulse turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 120.

Rain Dance.name: Rain Dance
description: Rain Dance causes a rain shower that lasts for 5 turns, and induces these additional effects:
The power of Water-type moves increases by 50%.
The power of Fire-type moves, Solar Beam and Solar Blade decreases by 50%.
The moves Thunder and Hurricane ignore accuracy.
In Diamond/Pearl only, Thunder has a 30% chance to break through Protect and Detect.
The moves Synthesis, Morning Sun and Moonlight recover 1⁄4 of the user's max HP (instead of 1⁄2 HP normally).
The move Weather Ball changes to Water type and doubles in power.
Pokémon with the ability Dry Skin recover 1⁄8 of their max HP each turn.
Pokémon with the ability Rain Dish recover 1⁄16 of their max HP each turn.
Pokémon with the ability Hydration will be cured of major status conditions.
Pokémon with the ability Swift Swim double their speed.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Rain Dance turns into Z-Rain Dance and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Aqua Tail.name: Aqua Tail
description: Aqua Tail deals damage with no additional effect.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Aqua Tail turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 175.

Shell Smash.name: Shell Smash
description: Shell Smash lowers the user's Defense and Special Defense by one stage each, while also raising Attack, Special Attack and Speed by two stages each.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each, or lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Shell Smash turns into Z-Shell Smash and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Iron Defense.name: Iron Defense
description: Iron Defense raises the user's Defense by two stages.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Steelium Z and uses its Z-Power, Iron Defense turns into Z-Iron Defense and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Hydro Pump.name: Hydro Pump
description: Hydro Pump deals damage with no additional effect.
In Generations 1-5, Hydro Pump has 120 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Hydro Pump turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 185.

Aqua Jet.name: Aqua Jet
description: Aqua Jet deals damage and has a priority of +1.
Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Aqua Jet turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 100.

Aqua Ring.name: Aqua Ring
description: The user of Aqua Ring surrounds itself with a veil of water, which restores 1⁄16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn.
If the user is holding a Big Root, Aqua Ring restores 30% more HP each turn - approximately 1⁄12 of its maximum.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Aqua Ring turns into Z-Aqua Ring and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Aura Sphere.name: Aura Sphere
description: Aura Sphere deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
In Generations 4-5, Aura Sphere has 90 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Fightinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Aura Sphere turns into All-Out Pummeling and has base power 160.

Fake Out.name: Fake Out
description: Fake Out attacks with a priority of +3 and causes the target to flinch if it hits. It is only successful on the first turn the Pokémon is in battle, but reset each time the Pokémon switches out and back in.
Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
In Generations 3-4, Fake Out has a priority of +1.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Fake Out turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.

Flail.name: Flail
description: Flail deals more damage the lower the user's HP. The following formula is used:
The value of N is then used to determine the base power, as per the table below. It converts to some quite specific percentages which are also shown.

In Generations 2-4, Flail used a multiplier of 64 instead of 48. The HP ranges corresponding to the base power list above are, respectively:0 - 3.12%3.13 - 9.35%9.36 - 20.30%20.31 - 34.37%34.38 - 67.18%67.19 - 100%
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Flail turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 160.

Haze.name: Haze
description: Resets all stat changes.
When a Pokémon is holding Icium Z and uses its Z-Power, Haze turns into Z-Haze and fully restores the user's HP, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Life Dew.name: Life Dew
description: Life Dew recovers up to 25% of the user's and its teammate's maximum HP.

Mirror Coat.name: Mirror Coat
description: When hit by a Special Attack, user strikes back with 2x power.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Mirror Coat turns into Shattered Psyche and has base power 100.

Mist.name: Mist
description: User's stats cannot be changed for a period of time.
When a Pokémon is holding Icium Z and uses its Z-Power, Mist turns into Z-Mist and fully restores the user's HP, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Muddy Water.name: Muddy Water
description: Muddy Water deals damage and has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Accuracy by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
In Generations 3-5, Muddy Water has 95 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Muddy Water turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 175.

Water Spout.name: Water Spout
description: Water Spout inflicts more damage when the user's HP is higher. At full HP its base power is 150 and it decreases in proportion - i.e. the power is:
Water Spout is a counterpart move to Eruption. It is also similar to Crush Grip and Wring Out, based on the user rather than the opponent.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Water Spout turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 200.

Yawn.name: Yawn
description: Yawn makes the target drowsy on the turn it is used. If the target is still on the field at the end of the next turn, it falls asleep. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns.
Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Yawn turns into Z-Yawn and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Flip Turn.name: Flip Turn
description: After making its attack, the user rushes back to switch places with a party Pokémon in waiting.
Flip Turn is a tutor move available in The Isle of Armor DLC.

Hail.name: Hail
description: Hail creates a hailstorm that lasts for 5 turns and induces these additional effects:
All Pokémon lose 1⁄16 of their max HP at the end of each turn, except Ice types and those with the abilities Ice Body, Magic Guard, Overcoat or Snow Cloak.
The move Blizzard ignores accuracy.
In Diamond/Pearl only, Blizzard has a 30% chance to break through Protect and Detect.
The move Aurora Veil may be used.
The power of Solar Beam and Solar Blade decreases by 50%.
The moves Synthesis, Morning Sun and Moonlight recover 1⁄4 of the user's max HP (instead of the usual 1⁄2 HP).
The move Weather Ball changes to Ice type and doubles in power.
Pokémon with the ability Ice Body recover 1⁄16 of their max HP each turn.
Pokémon with the ability Slush Rush double their speed.
Pokémon with the ability Snow Cloak increase their evasion by 20%.
Castform changes to Snowy Form.
When a Pokémon is holding Icium Z and uses its Z-Power, Hail turns into Z-Hail and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Ice Beam.name: Ice Beam
description: Ice Beam deals damage and has a 10% chance of freezing the target.
Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen.
In Generations 1-5, Ice Beam has 95 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Icium Z and uses its Z-Power, Ice Beam turns into Subzero Slammer and has base power 175.

Blizzard.name: Blizzard
description: Blizzard deals damage and has a 10% chance of freezing the target. It will hit both opponents in a double battle or adjacent opponents in a triple battle.
Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen.
During a hailstorm, Blizzard ignores accuracy.
In Generations 1-5, Blizzard has 120 base power.
In Generation 1, Blizzard has 90% accuracy.
In Diamond/Pearl only, Blizzard has a 25% chance of hitting through Protect or Detect during hail.
In the original Japanese Red/Green, Blizzard has a 30% chance to freeze the opponent.
When a Pokémon is holding Icium Z and uses its Z-Power, Blizzard turns into Subzero Slammer and has base power 185.

Scald.name: Scald
description: Scald deals damage and has a 30% chance of burning the target.
Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
If the user is frozen, Scald can be used and will thaw out the Pokémon before attacking.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Scald turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 160.

Brine.name: Brine
description: Power doubles if opponent's HP is less than 50%.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Brine turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 120.

Gyro Ball.name: Gyro Ball
description: Gyro Ball inflicts varying damage: the slower the user compared to the opponent, the higher the damage, up to a maximum base power of 150. The base power is calculated as:
For example, if the opponent is twice as fast as the user, Gyro Ball will have base power 50.
When a Pokémon is holding Steelium Z and uses its Z-Power, Gyro Ball turns into Corkscrew Crash and has base power 160.

Surf.name: Surf
description: Surf deals damage. In double battles it will hit all Pokémon on the field; in triple battles it will hit all adjacent Pokémon.
If the opponent is hidden underwater from using Dive, Surf will hit with double power.
In Generations 1-5, Surf has 95 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Surf turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 175.
Surf is used to cross water. While surfing, wild Pokémon may appear. It can only be used with the appropriate Gym Badge.
From Generation 3 onward it's possible to fish while surfing; previously one could only fish at the water's edge.

Waterfall.name: Waterfall
description: Waterfall deals damage and has a 20% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved).
Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
In Generations 1-3, Waterfall is categorized as Special.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Waterfall turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 160.
Allows a surfing Pokémon to ascend a waterfall. In Diamond, Pearl & Platinum, Waterfall is required to descend waterfalls, but in other games it is not.

Ice Punch.name: Ice Punch
description: Ice Punch deals damage and has a 10% chance of freezing the target.
Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen.
In Generations 1-3, Ice Punch is categorized as Special.
When a Pokémon is holding Icium Z and uses its Z-Power, Ice Punch turns into Subzero Slammer and has base power 140.

Icy Wind.name: Icy Wind
description: Icy Wind deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Icium Z and uses its Z-Power, Icy Wind turns into Subzero Slammer and has base power 100.

Whirlpool.name: Whirlpool
description: Whirlpool inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent in the vortex, causing them to lose 1⁄8 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns.
If the user holds a Grip Claw, the after-effects last for 7 turns. If a Binding Band is held, the damage is 1⁄6 of the target's maximum HP.
If the opponent is hidden underwater from using Dive, Whirlpool will hit with double power.
In Generations 2-4, Whirlpool has 15 base power.
In Generations 2-4, Whirlpool has 70% accuracy.
In Generations 2-4, the after-effects of Whirlpool last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5; holding Grip Claw they last for 5 turns.
In Generations 2-5, the target loses only 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, or 1⁄8 if a Binding Band is held.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Whirlpool turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 100.
Whirlpool allows you to cross swirling maelstroms in your path. Only Generation 2 and Generation 4 have whirlpools that can be passed.

Dive.name: Dive
description: The user of Dive will hide underwater on the first turn, disappearing from view and becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, Dive deals damage.

While underwater, the Pokémon can only be hit by the moves Surf, Whirlpool or Low Kick, with Surf and Whirlpool dealing twice normal damage. Moves from No Guard Pokémon, or any move following an identify move can also hit for regular power. The user also avoids end-of-turn damage from Sandstorm and Hail when underwater.
If the user is holding a Power Herb, Dive executes in one turn.
In Generation 3, Dive is categorized as Special.
In Generation 3, Dive has 60 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Dive turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 160.
While surfing, if you happen over a dark patch of water, you can dive below the surface and explore underwater. It can only be used with the appropriate Gym Badge.

Two regions have areas where you can use Dive: Hoenn (Ruby, Sapphire, Emerald, and the remakes Omega Ruby & Alpha Sapphire) and Unova (Black, White, Black 2, White 2) and the move is an HM in those games.

Zen Headbutt.name: Zen Headbutt
description: Zen Headbutt deals damage and has a 20% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved).
Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Zen Headbutt turns into Shattered Psyche and has base power 160.

Flash Cannon.name: Flash Cannon
description: Flash Cannon deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Steelium Z and uses its Z-Power, Flash Cannon turns into Corkscrew Crash and has base power 160.

Hydro Cannon.name: Hydro Cannon
description: User must recharge next turn.
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Hydro Cannon turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 200.

Avalanche.name: Avalanche
description: Power doubles if user took damage first.
When a Pokémon is holding Icium Z and uses its Z-Power, Avalanche turns into Subzero Slammer and has base power 120.

Dark Pulse.name: Dark Pulse
description: Dark Pulse deals damage and has a 20% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved).
Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
When a Pokémon is holding Darkinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Dark Pulse turns into Black Hole Eclipse and has base power 160.

Liquidation.name: Liquidation
description: May lower opponent's Defense. (20% chance)
When a Pokémon is holding Waterium Z and uses its Z-Power, Liquidation turns into Hydro Vortex and has base power 160.

Body Press.name: Body Press
description: The higher the user's Defense, the stronger the attack.

String Shot.name: String Shot
description: String Shot lowers the target's Speed by two stages.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generations 1-5, String Shot lowers Speed by one stage.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, String Shot turns into Z-String Shot and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Bug Bite.name: Bug Bite
description: Bug Bite deals damage, and if the target is holding a Berry, the user eats it and gains its effect. For example, if the target is holding a Sitrus Berry the user will recover 1⁄4 of its HP.
Bug Bite cannot steal a berry from a Substitute.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Bug Bite turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 120.

Electroweb.name: Electroweb
description: Electroweb deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Electrium Z and uses its Z-Power, Electroweb turns into Gigavolt Havoc and has base power 100.

Harden.name: Harden
description: Harden raises the user's Defense by one stage.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Harden turns into Z-Harden and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Gust.name: Gust
description: Gust deals damage with no additional effect.
However, it can hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stages of Bounce, Fly and Sky Drop - and in the case of Bounce and Fly, inflicts double damage.
In Generation 1, Gust is a Normal-type move.
In Generations 1-3, Gust is categorized as Physical.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Gust turns into Supersonic Skystrike and has base power 100.

Supersonic.name: Supersonic
description: Supersonic causes the target to become confused. Confused Pokémon have a 33% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 attacking turns (50% chance in Generations 1-6). The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack.
Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused. Soundproof also prevents this move.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Supersonic turns into Z-Supersonic and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Confusion.name: Confusion
description: Confusion deals damage and has a 10% chance of confusing the target.
Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Confusion turns into Shattered Psyche and has base power 100.

Stun Spore.name: Stun Spore
description: Stun Spore paralyzes the target, if it hits. Paralyzed Pokémon have a 25% chance of not being able to attack, and their Speed is decreased by 50% (75% in Generations 1-6).
Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Stun Spore turns into Z-Stun Spore and raises Special Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Psybeam.name: Psybeam
description: Psybeam deals damage and has a 10% chance of confusing the target.
Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Psybeam turns into Shattered Psyche and has base power 120.

Whirlwind.name: Whirlwind
description: In the wild, Whirlwind blows the target Pokémon away if they are of a lower level, and the battle ends.
In trainer battles (including linked battles), Whirlwind forces the target to switch out of battle (regardless of level) and is replaced with another Pokémon in the trainer's team.
Pokémon with the ability Suction Cups or those rooted by Ingrain are not affected by Whirlwind.
In Generation 1, Whirlwind has 85% accuracy.
In Generations 2-5, Whirlwind has 100% accuracy.
In Generation 1, Whirlwind has a priority of 0.
In Generation 2, Whirlwind has a priority of -1.
In Generation 3, Whirlwind has a priority of -5.
In Generations 1-4, Whirlwind can work on any level Pokémon in wild battles; its chance of failure is between 6% and 25%, with a higher level target giving a higher chance to fail.
In Generation 1, the move only causes wild battles to end with no effect in trainer battles.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Whirlwind turns into Z-Whirlwind and raises Special Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Bug Buzz.name: Bug Buzz
description: Bug Buzz deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Bug Buzz turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 175.

Tailwind.name: Tailwind
description: Tailwind doubles the speed of all Pokémon in the user's party for 4 turns.
In Generations 4-5, Tailwind has 30 PP.
In Generation 4, Tailwind lasts 3 turns instead of 4.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Tailwind turns into Z-Tailwind and raises critical-hit ratio one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Rage Powder.name: Rage Powder
description: Rage Powder redirects all single-target moves used by opponents to itself. It is only useful in double or triple battles.
It does not work for moves that target multiple Pokémon such as Air Cutter or Bulldoze.
In Generation 5, Rage Powder has a priority of +3.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Rage Powder turns into Z-Rage Powder and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Quiver Dance.name: Quiver Dance
description: Quiver Dance raises the user's Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed by one stage each.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Quiver Dance turns into Z-Quiver Dance and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Psychic.name: Psychic
description: Psychic deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generation 1, Psychic has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Special stat (Sp.Atk and Sp.Def combined).
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Psychic turns into Shattered Psyche and has base power 175.
When Mew is holding Mewnium Z and uses its Z-Power, Psychic turns into Genesis Supernova and has base power 185.

Shadow Ball.name: Shadow Ball
description: Shadow Ball deals damage and has a 20% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generations 2-3, Shadow Ball is categorized as Physical.
When a Pokémon is holding Ghostium Z and uses its Z-Power, Shadow Ball turns into Never-Ending Nightmare and has base power 160.

Thief.name: Thief
description: Thief deals damage and steals the target's held item, if the user is not holding an item.

Items stolen from wild Pokémon are kept after the battle ends, but items stolen from a Trainer's Pokémon are not. Items stolen from the player's Pokémon either by wild Pokémon or Trainer Pokémon are returned at the end of the battle. All held items in wi-fi/linked battles (including Battle Tower/Subway/Maison) are returned to their respective owners at the end of a battle.
If the item would activate on attack (e.g. Focus Band), it does so before being stolen. If the item is consumable on attack (e.g. Focus Sash) then the item is consumed as normal and cannot be stolen.

Pokemon with the ability Sticky Hold cannot have their held item removed. The Griseous Orb cannot be removed from Giratina; Type Plates cannot be removed from Arceus; Drives cannot be removed from Genesect; and Mega Stones cannot be removed from their respective Pokémon.
In Generations 2-3, Thief is categorized as Special.
In Generations 2-5, Thief has 40 base power.
In Generations 2-5, Thief has 10 PP.
In Generations 2-4, Thief steals a Trainer Pokémon's item permanently, but a wild Pokémon or a Trainer's Pokémon using Thief will not steal the player's item at all.
When a Pokémon is holding Darkinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Thief turns into Black Hole Eclipse and has base power 120.

Skill Swap.name: Skill Swap
description: The user swaps Abilities with the opponent.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Skill Swap turns into Z-Skill Swap and raises Speed one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Psych Up.name: Psych Up
description: Copies the opponent's stat changes.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Psych Up turns into Z-Psych Up and fully restores the user's HP, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Dream Eater.name: Dream Eater
description: Dream Eater deals damage only on sleeping foes and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained.

If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokémon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Dream Eater turns into Shattered Psyche and has base power 180.

U-turn.name: U-turn
description: User switches out immediately after attacking.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, U-turn turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 140.

Defog.name: Defog
description: Defog lowers the target's Evasion by one stage and removes entry hazards and barriers on both sides of the field. The moves affected are: Light Screen, Reflect, Mist, Safeguard, Spikes, Stealth Rock, Sticky Web and Toxic Spikes.

Defog also clears foggy weather in battle (which causes Accuracy loss when present), however this weather condition is only present in Sinnoh (Diamond/Pearl/Platinum) and cannot be created in battle otherwise.
In Generations 4-5, Defog only clears entry hazards on the target's side of the field.
In Generation 4, Defog could lower the Evasion of a target behind a substitute.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Defog turns into Z-Defog and raises Accuracy one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Defog can be used to clear foggy areas (fog will return upon leaving and re-entering the area). So far only Sinnoh has experienced foggy weather. In Diamond & Pearl, Defog cannot be used outside of battle before obtaining the Fen Badge (Pastoria City Gym); In Platinum it cannot be used before the Relic Badge (Hearthome City Gym).

Draining Kiss.name: Draining Kiss
description: Draining Kiss deals damage and the user will recover 75% of the HP drained.
When a Pokémon is holding Fairium Z and uses its Z-Power, Draining Kiss turns into Twinkle Tackle and has base power 100.

Baton Pass.name: Baton Pass
description: Baton Pass causes the user to switch out for another Pokémon, passing any stat changes to the Pokémon that switches in. These effects are passed:
Increases and decreases in Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed. For example the effects from Nasty Plot, Swords Dance and Screech (if targeted at the user of Baton Pass).
The sure hit effect from Lock-On and Mind Reader. In other words, after using either move followed by Baton Pass, the next move from the incoming Pokémon will always hit.
The confusion status ailment.
A Substitute, which keeps its remaining HP.
Trapping effects from Mean Look, Block and Spider Web, on both the user and opponent.
Critical hit ratio increase from the move Focus Energy or a Lansat Berry.
The HP-restoring effects of Aqua Ring and Ingrain.
The HP-depleting effect of Curse (when used by a Ghost-type on the user).
The effects of the moves Embargo, Gastro Acid, Magnet Rise, Perish Song and Power Trick.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Baton Pass turns into Z-Baton Pass and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Pollen Puff.name: Pollen Puff
description: Deals damage to opponent or restores HP of teammate.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Pollen Puff turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 175.

Poison Sting.name: Poison Sting
description: Poison Sting deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target.
Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
When a Pokémon is holding Poisonium Z and uses its Z-Power, Poison Sting turns into Acid Downpour and has base power 100.

Fury Attack.name: Fury Attack
description: Fury Attack hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown in the table, with the total power after each hit.
Each strike of Fury Attack is treated like a separate attack:
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
The Skill Link ability will cause Fury Attack to always hit the maximum number of times.
In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint.
In Generations 1-3, Fury Attack ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Fury Attack turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.

Fury Cutter.name: Fury Cutter
description: Fury Cutter deals damage starting at base power 40, and for each successful consecutive hit doubles in power, up to a maximum base power of 160.
If the move misses for any reason, the base power resets to 40.
In Generations 1-4, Fury Cutter has 10 base power.
In Generation 5, Fury Cutter has 20 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Fury Cutter turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 100.

Laser Focus.name: Laser Focus
description: User's next attack is guaranteed to result in a critical hit.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Laser Focus turns into Z-Laser Focus and raises Attack one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Focus Energy.name: Focus Energy
description: Increases critical hit ratio.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Focus Energy turns into Z-Focus Energy and raises Accuracy one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Assurance.name: Assurance
description: Assurance deals damage, and if the target has already taken damage in this turn its power doubles to 120.
In Generations 4-5, Assurance has 50 base power.
When a Pokémon is holding Darkinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Assurance turns into Black Hole Eclipse and has base power 120.

Toxic Spikes.name: Toxic Spikes
description: Toxic Spikes lays a trap of poisonous spikes around the foe, which poison Pokémon switching in to the opposing field. If used more than once, incoming Pokémon will be badly poisoned.

The spikes will not poison any raised Pokémon, nor does it affect Poison or Steel types, nor Pokémon with the abilities Immunity or Magic Guard. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary.

Toxic Spikes can be cleared from the field by the moves Rapid Spin (around the user) or Defog (around the target). Poison type Pokémon (that are not raised) will absorb the spikes upon switching in, removing their effect.
When a Pokémon is holding Poisonium Z and uses its Z-Power, Toxic Spikes turns into Z-Toxic Spikes and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Pin Missile.name: Pin Missile
description: Pin Missile hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown in the table, with the total power after each hit.
Each strike of Pin Missile is treated like a separate attack:
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
The Skill Link ability will cause Pin Missile to always hit the maximum number of times.
In Generations 1-5, Pin Missile has 14 base power.
In Generations 1-5, Pin Missile has 85% accuracy.
In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint.
In Generations 1-3, Pin Missile ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Pin Missile turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 140.

Poison Jab.name: Poison Jab
description: Poison Jab deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target.
Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
When a Pokémon is holding Poisonium Z and uses its Z-Power, Poison Jab turns into Acid Downpour and has base power 160.

Agility.name: Agility
description: Agility raises the user's Speed by two stages.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Agility turns into Z-Agility and eliminates any stat drops applied to the user, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Endeavor.name: Endeavor
description: Endeavor reduces the opponent's HP to equal the user's. (It fails if the user's HP is higher than the target's.)
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Endeavor turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 160.

Fell Stinger.name: Fell Stinger
description: Fell Stinger deals damage, and if the target is knocked out by this move, the user's Attack is raised by three stages.
Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
In Generation 6, Fell Stinger has 30 base power.
In Generation 6, Fell Stinger raises Attack by two stages instead of three.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Fell Stinger turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 100.

Peck.name: Peck
description: Peck deals damage with no additional effect, besides being able to hit non-adjacent Pokémon in triple battles.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Peck turns into Supersonic Skystrike and has base power 100.

Twineedle.name: Twineedle
description: Twineedle deals damage and will strike twice (with 25 base power each time). It has a 20% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Each strike of Twineedle is treated like a separate attack:
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
In Generations 1-2, Twineedle can poison Poison and Steel types.
In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint.
In Generations 1-3, Twineedle ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, Twineedle turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 100.

Rage.name: Rage
description: Rage deals damage, and if the user is hit by a direct attack - any time after Rage is first used but before a different move is used - the user's Attack is raised by one stage. The game will state the Pokémon's rage is building rather than explicitly assert the stat increase. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.

The Attack increases will continue as long as Rage is the last move used, even if it misses, the user is incapacitated (paralyzed, sleeping, etc) or the player uses an item. The Attack increase activates for every blow of multi-hit moves such as DoubleSlap or Fury Swipes.

As an example, if a Pokémon uses Rage then the opponent hits the user in the same turn, the user's Attack increases. If the user moves last it will not increase that turn, but will in the next turn if the opponent hits the user again.
In Generation 1, after Rage is selected it will continue to be used until the end of the battle or the user faints.

In Generations 2-3, if the user is slower than the opponent, the Attack rise only occurs if Rage is selected in that turn - if a different move is selected (or an item used) and the Pokémon is hit before it uses the new move, its Attack does not increase.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Rage turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.

Payback.name: Payback
description: Power doubles if the user was attacked first.
When a Pokémon is holding Darkinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Payback turns into Black Hole Eclipse and has base power 100.

X-Scissor.name: X-Scissor
description: X-Scissor deals damage with no additional effect.
When a Pokémon is holding Buginium Z and uses its Z-Power, X-Scissor turns into Savage Spin-Out and has base power 160.

Headbutt.name: Headbutt
description: Headbutt deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved).
Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Headbutt turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 140.
In Gold, Silver, Crystal, and the remakes HeartGold & SoulSilver, Headbutt can be used to shake trees. Often wild Pokémon will fall out; some Pokémon are only obtainable via this method.

Reflect.name: Reflect
description: Reflect reduces damage from Physical attacks by 50%, for 5 turns. Its effects apply to all Pokémon on the user's side of the field.
If the user is holding Light Clay when Reflect is used, its effects last for 8 turns.
The move Brick Break, when used against an Pokémon under Reflect's effect, will remove the screen before dealing damage. The ability Infiltrator bypasses the effects of Reflect.
Reflect is the Physical counterpart to Light Screen.
When a Pokémon is holding Psychium Z and uses its Z-Power, Reflect turns into Z-Reflect and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Mega Drain.name: Mega Drain
description: Mega Drain deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained.

If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokémon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
In Pokémon Let's Go Pikachu & Let's Go Eevee, Mega Drain has 75 base power.
In Generations 1-3, Mega Drain has 10 PP.
In Pokémon Let's Go Pikachu & Let's Go Eevee, Mega Drain has 10 PP.
When a Pokémon is holding Grassium Z and uses its Z-Power, Mega Drain turns into Bloom Doom and has base power 120.

Drill Run.name: Drill Run
description: Drill Run deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄24).
When a Pokémon is holding Groundium Z and uses its Z-Power, Drill Run turns into Tectonic Rage and has base power 160.

Sand Attack.name: Sand Attack
description: Sand Attack lowers the target's Accuracy by one stage. Although it is a Ground-type move it still affects raised Pokémon. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
In Generation 1, Sand Attack is a Normal-type move.
In Generations 1-5, this move's name is formatted as Sand-Attack.
When a Pokémon is holding Groundium Z and uses its Z-Power, Sand Attack turns into Z-Sand Attack and raises Evasiveness one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Quick Attack.name: Quick Attack
description: Quick Attack deals damage and has a priority of +1.
Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Quick Attack turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 100.

Twister.name: Twister
description: Twister deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved).
Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Twister can hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stages of Bounce, Fly and Sky Drop - and in the case of Bounce and Fly, inflicts double damage.
When a Pokémon is holding Dragonium Z and uses its Z-Power, Twister turns into Devastating Drake and has base power 100.

Feather Dance.name: Feather Dance
description: Feather Dance lowers the target's Attack by two stages.
Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
In Generations 3-5, this move's name is formatted as FeatherDance.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Feather Dance turns into Z-Feather Dance and raises Defense one stage, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Mirror Move.name: Mirror Move
description: User performs the opponent's last move.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Mirror Move turns into Z-Mirror Move and raises Attack two stages, in addition to its usual effect as above.

Razor Wind.name: Razor Wind
description: The user of Razor Wind will whip up a whirlwind on the first turn. On the second turn, Razor Wind deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄24).
If the user is holding a Power Herb, Razor Wind executes in one turn.
In Generations 1-3, Razor Wind is categorized as Physical.
In Generations 1-2, Razor Wind has 75% accuracy.
In Generation 1, Razor Wind does not have an increased critical hit ratio.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Razor Wind turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 160.

Brave Bird.name: Brave Bird
description: Brave Bird deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄3 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 90 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 30 HP.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Brave Bird turns into Supersonic Skystrike and has base power 190.

Uproar.name: Uproar
description: Uproar inflicts damage for 3 turns. During this time, no Pokémon on the field will be able to sleep, and any sleeping Pokémon will be woken up.
In Generation 3, Uproar is categorized as Physical.
In Generations 3-4, Uproar has 50 base power.
In Generations 3-4, the attack lasts 2-5 turns.
When a Pokémon is holding Normalium Z and uses its Z-Power, Uproar turns into Breakneck Blitz and has base power 175.

Pluck.name: Pluck
description: If the opponent is holding a berry, its effect is stolen by user.
When a Pokémon is holding Flyinium Z and uses its Z-Power, Pluck turns into Supersonic Skystrike and has base power 120.

Sky Attack.name: Sky Attack
